talk.start.para: - Did the Minister for Defence see in the Melbourne newspapers yesterday morning a report concerning a lecture given by Commander Creswell on wireless telegraphy at the United Service Club, and containing this passage -

quote.para: The distance to the Perth station was, approximately, 7,000 miles, while to Sydney via America, across which it was presumed the sound waves travelled, the distance was about 12,000 miles. talk.start.para: .- I move - That this Bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: This, and the measure immediately following, are rendered necessary by the peculiar circumstances under which this Parliament met. The original Act for the appointment of Public Works and Public Accounts Committees required the Committees to be appointed during the first session of the Parliament. The first session of this Parliament took place when portion of the old Senate was still in existence, and it was not then deemed advisable, or, indeed, right, to appoint the Committees under the then existing circumstances. The purpose of this measure is to provide that it shall be competent for this Parliament to appoint the Committees in the second session, which is the present session.

Clause 2 (Appointment of Committee). Senator GRANT (New South Wales) [11.19]. - I am. not satisfied with the delay in the presentation of the reports of the Committee to Parliament. I do not know how many hours per day, or how many days per week, they sit, or what they do, until their work is almost completed. The Vice-President of the Executive Council might give us an assurance that the Committee will present progress reports of the work they are doing at least once every fortnight.

talk.start.para: - Cannot we have the card system for them?
- No doubt, the members of the Committee carry out their work satisfactorily enough, but they should convey to Parliament more frequently an idea of the work they are performing.

. - I hardly think that Senator Grant his given this matter that profound thought which he generally gives to questions to which he addresses himself. If his suggestion were adopted, the Committees would frequently have to report that they were unable to report. All they could say, in the middle of an inquiry, was that they had examined so many witnesses, or visited so many places.
- That is what I wish to find out.

- The honorable senator's best way to ascertain it would be to secure inclusion on the Committee. He cannot be serious in asking for a progress report of that nature, which would be adding quite unnecessarily to the labours of the officials and the cost of printing.

. - The extra work would not occupy the time of the secretary or chairman of the Committee more than a few minutes, but the reports would enable us to know exactly what the Committee were doing. Under present conditions, they might sit for six weeks or six months, and we should know nothing of the work they perform. I should like to be apprised at frequent intervals of what they are doing, and would be glad of an assurance from the Minister on the subject.
. - I give the honorable sena tor the assurance that I will bring the matter under the notice of the Committee when appointed, to see if they can fall in with the suggestion.

speech.para: Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

talk.start.para: .- I move - That this Bill be now read a second time. The measure bears exactly the same relation to the Public Accounts Committee as 'the previous one did to the Public Works Committee.

.- Will the Vice-President of the Executive Council make a similar request to the Public Accounts Committ-ee as he has promised to make to the Public Works Committee, so that we may have at least! fortnightly a report of the work they are doing? It is very important in this age that we should know what is being done. If the card system is to be applied to ordinary workers, it is time something was done to see whether Committees of this kind are doing their work properly or not.
. - I shall place the suggestion before the Committee! I have no doubt they will receive it, as I do, as an indication that Senator Grant is a convert to the card system.

.-Would Senator Millen be prepared to adopt, with regard to this Committee, the card system prepared by the New South Wales Railways Commissioners ? I refer chiefly to the one under which sub-foremen are appointed to report each week what work is being done, the cost of the material, the material consumed, and, particularly, whether any of the members of the Committee are unsatisfactory or surplus. It is an excellent opportunity for the Senate to get exact information from its own members as to the working of the card system. I should not like the whole system to be introduced, because it might bring about a strike, but I should like card No. 6 to be applied.
- If you are not careful there will arise a public demand to apply the card system to this Chamber.

- That would be an excellent idea, as I might have the opportunity of being appointed a sub-foreman, with power to report that there were some surplus or unsatisfactory members here. I can quite see that the idea of extending the card system is gaining ground. I want to try it on this small Committee to ascertain if .it worth while introducing it, seeing that it is bringing about such disastrous results elsewhere.

. - The honorable senator has overlooked the fact that the adoption of the card system, as he suggests, would mean the appointment of foremen. That is quite unnecessary, because I take it that Senator Grant proposes to constitute himself foreman, to report whether the work of the Committee is being discharged satisfactorily or not.

In Committee (Consideration resumed from 13th September, vide page 2013) :

item.para: There shall be levied and paid on all war-time profits from any business to which this Act applies arising after the thirtieth day of June One thousand nine hundred and fifteen a tax (hereinafter referred to as " war-time profits tax") at such rate as is declared by the Parliament.
The war-time profits arising in a financial year shall be calculated as follows: -

item.label: (a)
item.para: toy ascertaining the monthly average of the profit or loss arising in the accounting period ending in the financial year and separately the monthly average of the profit or loss arising in the accounting period beginning in the financial year;
by multiplying the respective monthly averages of profit or loss (as the case may toe) by the number of months of the respective* accounting periods falling within the financial year;

item.label: (c)
item.para: by adding together the amounts of the profit or deducting the amount of the loss from the amount of the profit (as the case may be) and deducting from the sum so obtained the pre-war standard of profits as defined for the purposes of this Act; and

speech.para: Id) by deducting from the sum remaining in paragraph (c) hereof the deduction (if any) allowed by the next succeeding sub-section.

item.para: From the sum remaining under para-, graph (c) of the last preceding sub-section -

item.label: (a)
item.para: in the case of a business in which the pre-war standard of profits does not exceed Five hundred pounds, there shall toe deducted the sum of Two hundred pounds;
in all other cases, where the sum remaining under paragraph (o) .of the last preceding sub-section -

item.label: (i)
item.para: does not exceed Two hundred pounds, the total sum shall be deducted; (li ) exceeds Two hundred pounds, there shall be deducted the sum pf Two hundred pounds less -

item.label: (i)
item.para: in the financial year ending on the thirtieth day of June One thousand nine hundred and sixteen. One pound for every Two pounds by which the excess exceeds Two hundred pounds; (ii) in all succeeding financial years, One pound for every Four pounds by which the excess exceeds Two hundred pounds.

For the purposes of this Act the account ing period shall be taken to be the period of twelve months for which the accounts of the business have been made up for the purposes of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1015-1016, and where the accounts of any business have not been made up for any definite period, or for the period for which they have been usually made up, or a year or more has elapsed without accounts being made up, shall be taken to be such period not being less than six months or more than a year as the Commissioner determines ending on such a date as the Commissioner determines.

Where a business has not been in existence during the whole of the financial year or a business has changed ownership in a financial year this section shall have effect as if there were substituted for Two hundred pounds a proportionately reduced amount.

talk.start.para: . - This is the pivotal clause of the Bill, and I should like the Minister to explain clearly the reference made to the accounting period, and indicate how businesses would fare which issue their balance-sheets on 30th September, . 1915, which would be a couple or three months after the accounting period fixed. It seems to me that under the clause the fixing of the accounting period would create a good many complications in some cases. For instance, if a business balanced on 30th September, 1915, would that year be the pre-war year, or would the pre-war year be the year ended 30th September, 1914? If so, their would be a hiatus of nine months as between the accounting period and the date fixed for the commencement of the operation of the Bill, namely, 30th June, 1915. I should like some information on this point, so that business people may know clearly what sort of returns they should send in.

. - I understand that the specific question put by the. honorable senator is whether, in cases in which the accounting period ends on the 30th September, 1915, that period would commence on 30th September, 1914? My answer is that it would date from 30th September, 1913.
- What is to be done with the hiatus ?
- There is no hiatus.
- There is a hiatus of nine months.
- No. The last complete period before the outbreak of the war must be taken into consideration.
- Then what is to become of the period between the 30th September, 1913, and the 30th June, 1914?
- It will not count.
- Then there is a period that will not be taken into the taxpayer's calculations.
- Quite so. Otherwise we should have to compel him to revise his whole system of accounts, and to bring it up to the outbreak of the war.
- It is for the Department to come into line with business balances.
- The Department cannot do that. -

. - This matter must receive some consideration. The Vice-President of the Executive Council has admitted that there will be a hiatus of nine months in connexion with the balance-sheets of some businesses in the Commonwealth. There are many businesses which issue balance-sheets on 30th September each year, and in the compilation of their returns all of these will be obliged to go back nine months in order to establish a pre-war standard of profits. The nine months between 30th. September, 1913, and 30th June, 1914, will be lost. No account of it will be taken either one way or the other. I should like to see a provision made in the Bill for monthly averages to be taken from 30th September, 1913, to 30th June, 1915.

- The honorable senator must recognise that, the taxpayer is given the option of selecting any two out of the three years immediately prior to the war in order to determine his pre-war standard of profit.
- Will he be able to include this period jrro rata in his prewar standard ?
- Would any taxpayer do that?
- Some of the other clauses of the Bill provide for a pro ratd standard. This is another of the complexities of the measure which very few people understand.
- The honorable senator is responsible for that.
- I am not responsible for it. That responsibility rests on the Government which framed the Bill, practically on the lines of the Imperial Act.
- We have agreed to the second reading of the Bill. What is the use of the honorable senator complaining now ?
- He is not complaining. He is merely seeking information.

- I do not think that the Minister has been sufficiently clear on this point. I should like to know whether, in their decisions, the income tax authorities will be guided by the promises which have been made in both Houses of this Parliament during the consideration of the Bill? I am sure that as we proceed with this discussion we shall recognise the increasing difficulties of the measure. We shall certainly realize that one man, in the person of Mr. Ewing - wen if he were the Archangel Gabriel himself - will not be able to lay down equitable lines. It seems to me that regard should be paid by the income tax authorities to the pronouncements that are made by Ministers in both branches of the Legislature. I ask the Committee to consider whether this clause should not be entirely recast. On the admission of the Vice-President of the Executive Council himself, many businesses will have to drop out of their returns nine months of their business operations. The amendments made in another place in regard to the accounting period have tended towards simplicity, but that simplicity has not gone as far as it might go. At all events, this clause will result in losing the standard of profits of many businesses which balance on 30th September each year. The further we look into the measure the more complicated does it become.

. - The honorable senator has referred to this -clause as another of the complexities of the Bill. As a matter of fact it is as plain as 3. pikestaff. It is not a complexity, but a bogy that the honorable senator has raised. The purpose of the clause is to enable the Department to ascertain what was the taxpayer's pre-war standard of profit. To enable it to do this, it will take the last three balance-sheets upon which the taxpayer has based his income tax returns. It will not ask him to adjust a single figure in those returns. It will merely say to him, " Out of your last three complete years you may select the two years which are best from our point of view, and those two years shall determine your pre-war standard of profits." That is simplicity itself. The arrangement was devised to save the taxpayer from the complexity which would arise if he were required to bring his accounting period up to the date when this Bill will commence to operate. The period referred to by Senator Pratten as a hiatus might disclose either an increased or decreased profit. It is pure supposition as to which way it would work. While in some cases it might help the individual in others it might injure him.

. - In the case of a business which balances on 30th September, 1915, the Vice-President of the Executive Council would go back to the balance-sheet of 30th September, 1914, and the balance-sheets for the two previous years, in order to establish the pre-war standard of profit. It is clear, therefore, that no consideration will be given to the operations of any business which balances on 30th September in any year, in determining the pre-war standard as between 30th September, 1914, and 30th June, 1915.

. - I think it would be as well to make this accounting period as elastic as possible, otherwise it may work injury to some individuals. The Vice-President of the Executive Council has already pointed out that it is quite a simple matter for the taxpayer to select any two out of three pre-war years for the purpose of establishing his pre-war standard of profits. But if the taxpayer chooses to go to the trouble of making up another balance-sheet, I think that the Commissioner might very well consent to that procedure being adopted. If the individual were permitted to make up his balance-sheet, and to ignore the regular accounting period, an improvement would be effected in the measure. The same question will arise in sub-clause 12 of clause 16 of the Bill. If the Vice-President of the Executive Council can see his way to make the accounting period elastic, while more work will be thrown on the taxpayer, it may avoid hardship being inflicted upon him.
. - I really think honorable senators, possibly spurred by the presentation of the facts of a single case, are losing sight of the broader view of this matter.

speech.para: Assuming that the accounting period of a business terminated throughout the year as frequently in on month as in another, the worst that could . happen would be a six months' difference between the accounting period and the period when the tax would begin to operate. What can be the purpose of asking for a -special set of accounts in order to meet that six months ? In addition, it must be remembered that the taxpayer has the option of selecting any two out of three years immediately preceding the war as the basis of his pre-war standard of profits.

talk.start.para: - Why omit nine months of his pre-war trading operations if he balances on 30th September?
- We merely say to him, ""What profits have you been making for the past three years?"
- Omitting the nine months ?

- We give him the right to select any two out of the three pre-war years in determining his pre-war standard of profits. I would remind Senator Pratten that under another clause of the Bill, if the three pre-war years were years of abnormal depression in connexion with a particular business, those controlling it are entitled to take the. three previous years, so that they may not be unduly burdened by this taxation. What the honorable senator proposes is that if the owner of a business made abnormal profits during the nine months immediately preceding the war, he might include them in his accounting period, in order to raise his pre-war standard of profits, and if he had a bad time during those nine months he could avail himself of the option given him under the Bill and go back to the earlier years. However much an honorable senator may be interested in the business' of particular firms or individuals, that does not seem to me to be a reasonable thing to ask.
- I 'do not know of a single individual case. I am speaking generally of firms balancing on the 30th September.

- No greater number balance on the 30th September than the number balancing on the 30th June. There would be, on an average, six months' interval between a firm's financial year and our financial year, and, in view of the concessions made to taxpayers permitting them to pick their own period of two years out of the three years prior to the war, in order to estimate their prewar standard of profits, I think the Committee would not be justified in any alteration of the clause now under review, in the way suggested by Senator Pratten.

. - I did not speak on the second reading of this Bill because I considered that this is a baby which the present Government should have to carry themselves. I believe they will find it a very heavy baby before they are finished with it.
- Honorable senators opposite are making the baby restive.

- I know that, when this Bill was first introduced in another place, many communications were received by members from business firms complaining that the fixing of the accounting period in the way proposed would be likely to inflict great hardship upon them. I know that some firms of auditors audit the books of many of the businesses in a particular street. The accounts of one firm are audited at the end of one month, and of another firm at the end of the next month. Under this Bill, firms whose accounts are audited on the 30th July will have to go back twelve months to fix the pre-war standard.

talker.name: MILLEN, Edward
Senator MILLEN

talk.start.para: - We do not ask them to do that.

- I frankly admit that I do not understand this measure, and do not think that anybody else does, and I want some explanation. I had an opportunity of going through the books of one firm, and I find that they made a clear profit of 14,000 in one year, whilst in the next year they made a profit of only 1,200. In this case, by reckoning the accounting period in one way, the business would have to pay this tax on the good year, but by* reckoning it in another way it would escape on the bad year. I believe that an amendment of this particular provision was made in another place. One business balancing on the 30th July will have to go back for twelve months and pay the tax, and another business being carried on next door, whose balancing period is different, may escape scot free.

speech.para: Senator MILLEN" (New South Wales - Vice-President of the Executive Council) [11.49]. -A business will not be t allowed to go scot free. The object of the clause is to ascertain the profits made by a firm or business -prior to the war, and for this purpose the ordinary balance-sheets of a firm are taken. The war broke out on the 4th August, and, in order to determine what a firm made in pre-war years, we take what the books show that it made in its last financial years prior to the war, and accept that as the prewar standard. The alternative is to ask the business man to revise the whole of his bookkeeping, and draw up a balance-sheet to the 3rd August, though his ordinary practice may be to balance on the 31st December. We give him the right to take the last three years prior to the war, and the option of taking the- two years of those three which best suit him. That, I think, may be regarded as a concession which will more than compensate for any little disadvantage which in particular cases might arise from adherence ito the accepted accounting period.

talk.start.para: . - I do not think that the Minister quite understands the point.
-. - I have been thinking that of some of the critics.

- We should deal with every taxpayer alike. The purpose of the Bill is to discover what were the profits of a business prior to the war. Under this clause, a firm balancing some months prior to the 4th August may be prevented from taking advantage of what may have been a very profitable period in estimating its pre-war profits. If the accounting period were made- elastic, a business would be given the opportunity of including that profitable time in its accounting period. I do not see why there should be any objection to that. I do not think that, because a firm balances its books at a particular time, it should he asked to cut out possibly a very profitable period of nine months and thirty days in estimating its pre-war profits. If the taxpayer, with the consent of the Commissioner, is willing to go to the trouble and expense of making up a balance-sheet to the 4th August, apart from his customary balance-sheet, there should be no objection to his doing so.

- Does the honorable senator not see that a man could not today take stock of the stock he had in hand two years ago. The only way to deter mine the matter is to turn to his balance-sheets when stock was taken at the regular periods.

- Where it would be impossible, the business man would not ask that it should be done, and the Commissioner might object ; but there are many businesses to which the honorable senator's objection would npt apply, and in connexion with which a balance-sheet might be made up at any time. I can see possibilities of great hardship, under this clause. Merely for the purpose of taxing a man we should not make fish of one and flesh of another, and I repeat that I would like to see some elasticity in, the accounting period provided for.

. - I do not desire to labour this point, but I remind the Minister that in sub-clause 12 of clause 16 the pre-war years are defined in this way - " The last pre-war trade year " means the year ending at the end of the last accounting period before the 5th day of August, 1914, and " the last three pre-war trade years " means the three years ending at the three corresponding times.

speech.para: Clearly, under this, pre-war years, in the case of . businesses balancing on 30th September, or on 31st December, go back as from 30th September and 31st December, 1913. Suppose a business were established, and its first balance-sheet was issued on 30th September, 1913-

talk.start.para: - That is a business established for only one year ?

- Yes. Would that business, in view of this clause, be brought under the pre-war standard, or would the Commissioner of Taxation insist that in that case there was no prewar standard because the business had existed only for one year and nine months before the war, and therefore levy the tas on the percentage basis?
- The honorable senator will see that, in paragraph b of the proviso to sub-clause 3 of clause 16, there is specific provision made to meet such a case.

- I see that that is so. . I have to ask another question. If a business is balanced on 30th September, 1914, will it be taxed on the pre-war standard, or will the Commissioner insist on assessing the profits on a percentage basis ?
- In clause 15 the honorable senator will find that provision is made that in such a case the tax will be levied upon 10 per cent, of the capital, or 1,000, whichever is the greater.

- In other words, the levy will be upon the percentage standard just as if there are no pre-war profits. I think the Government would be well advised to consider whether, in connexion with fixing the pre-war standard, the balancing day nearest to 4th August, 1914, should be taken. I will leave this point, and will later refer to other parts of the clause. I remind the Committee that there are fifty-five lines of the Bill covered by this clause. I am not clear as to what is really meant by sub-clause 3, and I should he glad if the Minister will explain its incidence.
.- I do not think that the honorable senator can be serious in suggesting that I should get up and give a full explanation of each clause as it is submitted to the Committee.
- I referred to subclause 3 of this clause.

- The honorable senator has had the Bill before him, and has evidently given it careful study, and, if he is asking me to explain the incidence of each clause as it is put to the Committee, he is asking too much.

.- Senator Millen, with his experience of Parliament, will admit the temptation that is offered to the Opposition to join in the debate upon this Bill, and will scarcely expect me to' maintain the neutrality of attitude which I took up on the second reading. In moving the second reading of the Bill, the honorable senator admitted that it is an intricate measure, and said that it lent itself more to explanation in Committee.
- Certainly, when specific points are raised.

- My colleague from New South Wales has asked the Minister for an explanation of sub-clause 3. That is a fair request, because the whole clause is the most complicated in the Bill, and I do not think it has been suggested that we should hurry in our discussion of the measure. The explanation has been asked for, and I think it will expedite matters' if the Minister will give it. Personally, I have been anxious to see the clause passed, so that we may consider the following clause, to which I propose to move some amendments. I think, also, that an explanation would help as a guide to those officials who will have the responsibility of administering the Act.

. - Senator Pratten has already shown that he knows the purport of this clause, because he has been combating it* and yet he asks me now for an explanation of what he regards as an iniquitous; and wrong principle. The honorable* senator can hardly expect me to do what he has already shown to be unnecessary. We propose, for the purpose of ascertaining the pre-war standard, to allow a taxpayer to take any of the two completed accounting periods according to the manner in which he has been keeping his books.
- But this clause has to be read in conjunction with several other clauses.
- Senator Prattenknows the purpose of the clause, because he has been combating it for the last halfhour.

speech.para: Senator PRATTEN (New South Wales) [12.3J. - The Minister is not showing his usual perspicuity in regard to the matter. He is under a total misapprehension in regard to what has been asked. So far, we have been discussing sub-clause 2 of clause 7, which is a machinery clause, dealing with the prewar standard and the accounting period. We had finished with that sub-clause, and I was asked for information with respect to sub-clause 3.

talk.start.para: - We have been discussing sub-clause 4.
- No. Sub-clause 3 o has not yet been discussed. ' This states -

quote.para: In the case of a (business in which .the prewar standard of profits does not exceed 500, there shall be deducted the sum of 200.

speech.para: That has nothing to do with the date of balancing a business. It relates to the deduction to be allowable in certain cases, and it is most complicated.
Senator MILLEN (New South Wales - Vice-President of the Executive Council) was discussing the question of the prewar standard, which is covered by subclause 4.

talk.start.para: . - Sub-clause 4 states -

quote.para: For the purposes of this Act, the accounting period shall be taken to be the period of twelve months for which the accounts of the business have been made up for the purposes of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1915-16. . . . I would like to know if the Commissioner will have the same power as the Income Tax Commissioner, to allow taxpayers to go back one month in their accounting period.

talk.start.para: . - No. The taxpayer must show a complete twelve months, according to the manner in which His books have been kept. He will be allowed to select any two of the three pre-war trade years.

. - The Minister has not quite understood what I meant to convey. The Income Tax Assessment Act gives the Commissioner authority to allow any firm to make the accounting period Up to the end of July instead of June. Will the Commissioner, under this wartime profits tax, have the same power!
- No.

. - All the States have income tax laws in operation; and with regard to the measure now under discussion, I would suggest that the taxpayer be allowed to select two of the three pre-war trade years in accordance with the income tax returns furnished by him to any State or Federal authority.

speech.para: Senator MILLEN (New- South Wales Vice-President of the Executive Council) [12.91. - I would again point out that under this Bill- it is proposed to allow a taxpayer to select his own accounting period ; and if it conforms to the accounting period covered by State income 'tax returns, we should naturally be adopting that period. -

talk.start.para: - But this does not deal with the date of balancing a business.

- We know what is behind this objection to the clause. A few businesses made tremendous profits just before the war broke out, and some would come under this provision if it were inserted in the Bill - thus they would be able to establish a higher pre-war standard, and would get a tremendous advantage.
- You want to get at them.
- There is no desire to do anything in an unfair way; but, seeing that they will have the right to take any of the three pre-war trade years, they will be suffering no injustice.

.- I hope that during the discussion of this Bill in Committee there will be no suggestion that any honorable senator has any axe to grind. I am not concerned with one single business that will be affected, either adversely or profitably ; but as one having some experience of the commercial section of this great Commonwealth, I do know that business houses, as a rule, balance at quarterly intervals, either at 30th June, 30th September, 31st December, or 31st March ; or, alternatively, on the 1st of October, January, April, or July. The Leader of the Senate should l._ suggest that there is something behind this action on the part of honorable senators who are criticising the clause. It is clear that there is some anomaly in the Bill. It has been admitted that in the case of a business balancing on the 30"Bh September, that business will have to go back' nine months before it commences its pre-war standard. I say, most deliberately, that I have no axe to grind. Now that the second reading has been- agreed to, I desire to try to improve the Bill; and. - in this respect, before the clause passes, I should like to direct attention to the discretionary power given to the Commissioner. Sub-clause 4 gives that official discretionary power to determine the accounting period in certain cases; and in thirty-seven different places throughout the Bill the Commissioner has discretionary power invested in him in some form or other.
- And Senator Fairbairn wanted to give him more power.

- I am raising the broad principle of the discretion given to the Commissioner. However capable that gentleman may be - and I believe, he is here now - however keen he may be, and however full of knowledge of the whole of our trading, commercial, and manufacturing conditions, if he were the Archangel Gabriel he would not be able to determine, in a manner satisfactory to the commercial community, all the questions that will come before him. At another time, and in another clause, I shall bring this matter seriously before the

speech.para: Committee. No doubt it is far the easiest thing to do to end the discussion and close up Parliament next week ; but I say, with all deliberation, that the commercial community of this country has not had too good a time in connexion with the discretion of the Income Tax Commissioner. Chambers of Manufactures, business men, and Chambers of Commerce, ever since the income tax has been levied, have been protesting against some injustice under that Act. I can quote one injustice in connexion with machinery. Up to now, the Commissioner has in about nine cases out of ten refused to allow more than 5 per cent, for depreciation. It is-quite true that he allows for renewals and repairs, but any purchase of new machinery has to be added to capital. In the case of automatic machinery, such as is used in tin-can making, in confectionery establishments, or in some of the more intricate of engineering work, the Commissioner will not allow more than 5 per cent, for depreciation; and anybody acquainted with manufacturing will know that machinery is not supposed to last for twenty years. This discretionary power to be invested in the Commissioner appears frequently in this Bill. I have with me papers wherein protest after protest has been made by representatives of organizations; but, owing to.: the congestion of war work, these protests have merely been noted; and probably pigeonholed. I am bringing this question up now, so that there shall be no mistake as to what the discretion of the Commissioner means. If it is going to mean, in the thirty-seven clauses where it is given, the same power as it has meant in connexion with the depreciation of machinery, then God help the new industries. Even the State Government will allow 10 per cent., which is a fair thing; but the difference between the 5 per cent, allowed by the Commonwealth and the 10 per cent, allowed by the State is a robbery from the profits which are made by industrial concerns.

talk.start.para: .- I join with Senator Pratten in resenting .the imputation of the Vice-President of the Executive Council (Senator Millen), that there is something behind this discussion. I did not rise to prolong the debate on that account, but to suggest to Senator Pratten that he should submit amendments, and let us deal with them on their merits. If the debate is continued on the lines of criticising a clause and asking the Minister for an explanation, it will be interminable. Therefore, with the view to expedite the consideration of the measure, I suggest to Senator Pratten that, in regard to clauses which are not satisfactory from his stand-point, he should submit definite amendments to improve them. I am sure that if that course were taken we would get on more expeditiously, and also more satisfactorily. I suggest to the Leader of the Senate, too, that he should reserve his gibes, and use them, as he has used them in the past, for the Opposition only. I earnestly appeal to him to refrain from this sort of conduct, because I can see that his gibes hurt a new member of the Senate.

item.para: The businesses to which this Act applies are all businesses (whether continuously carried on or not) of any description deriving profits from sources , within Australia, excepting

item.label: (a)
item.para: businesses carried on -by a municipal corporation' or other local governing body or by a public authority; or by a society registered under a Friendly Societies Act of the Commonwealth or a State or Territory, and not carried on for pecuniary profit; or by or for the exclusive benefit of a religious, charitable, or public educational institution; or any company carrying on the business of life insurance so far as regards its life insurance business, but not excluding so much of the profits of that business as is available for distribution to the shareholders; and

agriculture, fruit-growing, the maintenance of dairy herds for the supply of dairy products, pig and poultry raising, and the business of cooperative companies engaged for the main part in the manufacture, preparation, or wholesale distribution of foodstuffs, the produce of Australia; and

item.label: (o)
item.para: offices or employments; and

item.label: (d)
item.para: any profession the profits of which de pend mainly on the personal qualifications of the person by whom it is carried on, and in which comparatively little or no capital expenditure is required; and

item.label: (e)
item.para: businesses where the principal business consists of mining for gold: and (/) businesses commenced since the fourth day of August, 1914, which, in the opinion of the Commissioner, derive the whole of their profits from the recovery from waste manufactured products of any materials which are used for the production of munitions of war, but including the business of any person taking commissions in respect of any transactions or services rendered, and of any agent of any description (not being a commercial traveller, or an agent whose remuneration consists wholly of a fixed and definite sum not depending on- the amount of business done or any other contingency ) . (3.) When any resident of Australia, who is on active service outside Australia with the naval or military forces of any of the Allied Powers in connexion with the present war, is. the owner of, or is a partner in a business to which this Act applies, and who before he went on active service devoted the whole or the greater part of his time in connexion with the management of the business, and whose military or naval duties require him to be in any part of the field of operations in connexion with the1 war where there is danger to life as a result of the operations of enemy forces, such person shall -

item.label: (a)
item.para: when the sole owner of a business be exempt from liability to pay the wartime profits tax ; [b) when a partner in a business been titled to a refund from the Commissioner of the part of the tax payable by the partnership which bears the same proportion to the tax payable by the partnership as his interest in the profits of the partnership bears to the total profits.

talk.start.para: . - I wish to insert after the word "Australia," in paragraph b, the following words: - so far as regards the manufacture, preparation, or wholesale distribution of foodstuffs, the produce of Australia.

speech.para: The paragraph exempts from the operation of the tax businesses relating to agriculture, fruit-growing, the maintenance of dairy herds for the supply of dairy products, pig and poultry raising, and the business of co-operative .companies engaged for the main part in the manufacture, preparation, or. wholesale distribution of foodstuffs the produce of Australia. The insertion of the words I have just read would limit any exemption which a company had to profits made in the manufacture, preparation, or wholesale distribution of foodstuffs the produce of this country.

talk.start.para: . - Before that amendment is proposed, sir, I desire to move - _ That paragraph 6 be amended by the omission of the words " and the business of cooperative companies engaged for the main part in the manufacture, preparation, or wholesale distribution of foodstuffs, the produce of Australia."

speech.para: A co-operative company is a class of company which we all wish to encourage as much as possible, but there are a number of companies carrying on business which have really become proprietary companies; they are exactly the same. There is a general feeling in favour of doing away with the middleman. We want to encourage farmers or fruit-growers to come together and form co-operative companies. But cooperative companies have no business, so far as- 1 can see, to pay dividends or to make profits at all. The basic idea of a co-operative company is that only the actual cost of the distribution of the products should be charged to each individual. The original object in starting a number of these companies was to escape the large charges which were imposed upon them. But they have drifted very far from that aim, and there are n6w a great number of co-operative companies which are neither more nor less than trading concerns, carrying on just the same as ordinary agents who are trading alongside of them. If we exempt co-operative companies of that character from this tax we shall enable a company to trade against an ordinary commission agent who is alongside, and very often a poor man starting in business. It does not appear to me that that would be fair. Some of the wealthier co-operators buy lt he shares of the smaller co-operators, and then they declare large dividends. My view is that 0a co-operative company has no business to make money. We are asked to exempt these companies from a tax on war-time profits, something which they have made over and above what they made in ordinary times. That seems to me a great anomaly. I hope that Senator Millen will see his way to cut these companies out of the Bill, because the idea of a cooperative company making war-time profits, or profits at all, is ridiculous.

talk.start.para: - Their only object is to save costs to the producers.
- That is so.
- They must pay interest on the capital they use.
- That is quite understood; but if they pay interest they cannot make war-time profits. No hardship would be inflicted upon a cooperative company if it were not exempted from this tax.
- It would not pay any tax though, either way.

- I know dozens of companies which started as cooperative companies, but which are now Ordinary trading concerns, the same as any other agency companies. If we put bastard co-operative companies in a favorable position by exempting them from the tax on war-time profits, we shall enable them to swallow up all the small agents in this country.
- Who first acquired the shares in the companies to which you refer ?

- A company was started, and there were so many shares representing the capital originally paid in. The richer men in the company bought out the poorer men. The smaller co-operator, as a rule, gets hard up, and sells his shares to the richer co-operator, who then becomes the owner of the cooperative company, and it trades exactly the same as an ordinary company. I, do not think that we would inflict any hardship if we did not exempt these companies from the tax. If they make war- time profits, they should pay the tax.

. - I have a prior amendment to move, sir. I intend to move the omission of all the words from the words " educational institution," in paragraph a, down to and including the words " services rendered," in paragraph /.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1910; LP from 1913; NAT from 1917
talker.name: MILLEN, Edward
Senator MILLEN

talk.start.para: - I take it that the effect of that proposal will be to strike out all the exemptions in the Bill.

- Practically all the exemptions of businesses. I do not propose to strike out the exemptions in regard to profits which are not taxed. What the Bill purports to do is to tax war-time profits. Yet the Committee is asked to adopt that method of holding the balance fairly between two different kinds of businesses. Take a produce business which is conducted by a co-operative concern, in opposition to a profits business which belongs to an ordinary company, and, therefore, is not co-operative, or which is carried on by a single individual. Why should two businesses, making equal profits and run on the same business lines, have to pay a war-time profits tax, and another business have no tax to pay? That differentiation should not be allowed.

speech.para: I may be accused of wanting to tax agriculture. Suppose that after a man had been farming for some years he found that it would be more profitable to dispose of his farm and buy a business. Suppose that he sold his farm to a man who had been engaged in a business for some time, and with the proceeds bought that business. By bringing business methods to bear on the work of farming the new farmer finds that, owing to the increased prices for his produce in war time he is making a handsome return, perhaps a fortune. Although the old farmer has invested his capital in a business, he finds that the whole, or the greater part, of his return during the war period goes into the business. If it is to be a war-time profits tax, let it bear evenly upon all shoulders.

talk.start.para: - When you say " a war-time profits tax," are you using a phrase which is synonymous with wartime profits?
- If we were to call this a tax on excess war-time profits it would probably be a more accurate description.
- I rise to order, sir. I draw your attention to the fact that there are two speeches going on in the chamber just now.
- I do not mind that, sir. It rather helps me to have conversations going on around me, but I thank the honorable senator all the same.
- Order !

- Under the provisions of this Bill the farmer who sold his farm and bought a business would have to pay a huge tax. But the man who sold out of the business, and went into farming, would be allowed his profits. If that is the position, we are legislating for one class of the community against the other, whereas legislation should be evenly balanced, and we should aim at dealing out even-handed justice to all sections.
- I should like you to emphasize the principle of equity that should obtain.

- That is what I am aiming at. Taking a comprehensive view of the clause, we must meet with failure if we say, " This man shall be exem.pt, and that man shall not; this interest shall be exempt, and this one shall not." However, we have the Bill before us as the result of the recent elections. The people asked for it, we promised it to them, they are going to get it, and as I want them to get it in the shape that will be most acceptable to them, I move, as a test amendment -

quote.para: That after the words " educational institution " in sub-clause 1 paragraph a, the word " or," be left out.

speech.para: If that is carried I shall move that all the exemptions I indicated be struck out.

talk.start.para: . - I believe, in the words of the Prime Minister, " We must look to the wealthy people to provide the money to carry on this war ; everybody must pay ; none shall escape." But by this Bill more will escape than are going to pay. It is going to strangle some rising industries that we should foster, while allowing others who have made large profits during the war to escape. Why is the agriculturist exempted? Why is the pastoralist exempted? They have all made money during the war . whereas the business of a man who is trying to produce something that is necessary for the industries of this country is to be strangled. I have previously mentioned a firm producing fire-bricks, a necessary article which has to be imported if it is not made here. They have spent 25,000 in perfecting this silesia brick, they made no profits until last year, and now they are going to be taxed on those profits. Opposite their factory, in New South Wales, there is a pastoralist's run; he has made enormous profits out of the sale of beef during the war, but he is to escape scot-free.
- Pastoralists are not exempt.
- The newspapers have been misleading the public on that point.

- At any rate, the agriculturists are to escape. The Bill has been brought forward by a Government composed of two sections which have been diametrically opposed to one another i-i their methods of taxation in the past. It hardly seems possible that they could bring in a Bill which would give satisfaction to all their following. If, even at this late hour, we struck out all the exemptions except those of charitable institutions we would make it much more just than it is, because now it picks out certain incomes for taxation and others for exemption. The only fair way to deal with it is to strike out the whole of the exemptions, and let every one pay on the same basis.

speech.para: Senator EARLE (Tasmania) [12.351.- I am sorry I cannot support Senator Gardiner's proposal to abolish all exemptions. I realize the truth of what he has said regarding the hardship which, may be inflicted on some business men, but there are certain industries in this country which at a time like this must be particularly guarded and fostered. While doing that, we must recognise that the purpose of the Bill must be carried out, which is to get extra revenue from the source which is most able to afford it, and which in the interests of Australia we can most legitimately levy on.

talk.start.para: - Do you think the man who grows wheat should be exempt, and the man who grows wool should be taxed ?

- The man who grows wool is probably in quite a good position, owTng to the demand for wool and the high price, to pay extra taxation at a time like this. At no period in 'the history of any country has it been more important that the protection or fostering of the primary industries for the production of the necessaries of life in Australia should be undertaken. On the 6th August, 1914, speaking to a body of miners to try to induce them to continue working, I said the man behind the plough or behind the pick before this war was over would be of equal importance with the man behind the gun. That expression stands good today. Following up that policy, the Government of which I was Premier advanced a considerable sum for the purchase of seed wheat to give the farmers every opportunity to prosecute this policy of production. The farmers in Tasmania took advantage of it, and acres of land went under cultivation which had not been under cultivation before. We have to follow the same policy, and, although we are under difficulties at the present time to get our wheat away, I am sanguine that they will be overcome. Every bushel of wheat and other agricultural produce that can be exported will be of the utmost value to the Allies before the war is over.
- Yes, if the policy cf building ships is stimulated and encouraged by allowing ship-builders to earn profits.

- Honorable senators seem .to follow the policy that because there is something in the Bill which is wrong, they are going to put something in which is as bad or worse. I will help the honorable senator to exempt shipbuilders from the payment of this tax. It is a new industry, essential to the interests of Australia. I will help to exempt from the tax new industries which, as Senator McDougall pointed out. are of vital importance to the nation. If, by grasping at the increased revenue to be derived from this tax. we retard the introduction and establishment of industries which will be for all time an advantage to the Commonwealth, we shall be grasping at the shadow and losing the substance. Vital and important as it is that we should have money for the prosecution of the war, we must not get it at the expense of retarding the industries cf Australia. The producing industry is of such importance, particularly at this time, that there is a justification for its exemption from the Bill. Hence, while I am prepared to assist to exempt new industries which have been started or are about to be started, and to remove exemptions from such persons as professional men, many of whom, I believe, receive considerably increased incomes in consequence of the war, I cannot vote to remove from the list of exemptions an industry which is vital to the interests of the nation and its Allies. I noted Senator Gardiner's illustration of the farmer and the business man changing places, but the farmer is carrying on a business of vital importance to the nation, and the other goes into the trading business, which, although useful, is not vital. I admit it is hard on him to tax him in this way - it is hard on anybody to have to pay an excess fax - but if we are going to have a Bill at all. we cannot avoid it. We must- pass a Bill of this kind, and if we find anomalies in it, we must submit to them. We cannot meet all such objections as that raised by Senator Gardiner if we are going to have an excess profits tax at all. I recognise the force of his argument, but it is impracticable to carry out his wishes.
. - I intend to vote for the omission of all the exemptions. Going back to the genesis-
- Let us have Revelations first.

- The revelations will come in about three or six months from the honorable senator's constituents, when they begin to feel the complications of this Bill. The policy of the National Government was to impose a war-time profits tax, and it was announced, even by the Leader of the Government in this Chamber (Senator Millen), that all those persons who make extra profits in war time ought to be taxed. With such a long list of exemptions, this Bill will not tax all those persons who have made extra profits during the war. I have every sympathy with the man on the land, but I fail to see why an extra profit made by a fruit-grower, for example, should not be taxed if ,an -extra profit made by the man who dries that fruit is to be taxed. I cannot see why an extra profit made in wheat-growing should not be taxed equally with an extra profit made by the millers in rolling that wheat. I fail to understand why a doctor should escape this taxation when an agent is to be subjected to it. I cannot see why, under this Bill, an accountant, a solicitor, or a barrister should not be required to pay when a broker is to be taxed. There is no fairness whatever in the exemptions contained in the measure. Gold-mining is to be exempted from its operation, but tin-mining - although tin is of no greater average value since the war than it was- in the three years immediately prior to the war - is to be taxed. . Many of the wealthy mining companies in Australia have already exempted themselves from this proposed taxation by making no greater profits during the war period, despite the rise that there has been in the value of metals, than they made prior to the war. Last night I saw the balance-sheet of one of these companies, which fully confirms all that I said in this connexion on the motion for the second reading of the Bill. If we must have a measure of this kind let us tax- everybody who m,akes an extra profit, and exempt nobody. When once we commence to make exemptions we begin to complicate the issue. I hope that the amendment will be carried, but my attitude towards it has not been influenced by the fact that it has been submitted by ' the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Gardiner). No m.atter how heavy may be the taxation that is imposed upon the trading and mercantile community of Australia, there will be far less dissatisfaction, if we impose a heavy tax which will hit everybody alike, than there will be if we impose p, light tax which will make flesh of one and fowl of another. I shall vote for the elimination of all exemptions. If the amendment is defeated I shall propose a new clause which will exempt somebody else.
. - I am not sure that Senator Gardiner's amendment is sufficiently comprehensive.
- There is one very prominent business . which has been omitted from it.

- Possibly. I am Very much amazed at the keen interest that is exhibited in the Bill by honorable senators of the Ministerial party. They seem to realize that under its operation a large number of their constituents will be asked to p,y something towards the national 'revenue, and, apparently, that payment will be a very unpleasant procedure. There appears to be one striking inconsistency in this clause. Why should we tax any person's business if we permit a solicitor to go soot-free? Surely if we are prepared to fasten on to a flour miller, and to make him pay this tax, solicitors and barristers ought .also to be obliged to contribute to the national exchequer ! Of course, it is impossible to accurately ascertain what fees solicitors earn. Some of them do not make very much, but others make substantial incomes
- Do not they pay income tax?
- And other persons who will be subjected to the operation of this Bill also pay income tax.
- Only if they make profits as the result of the war.

- If a man is making a profit during the war period he ought to be required to pay the tax. The distinction between war profits and war-time profits is a little too fine for me to appreciate. Seeing that we are bound to collect a great deal of money to enable us to prosecute the war, we ought not to countenance such a distinction. It has been asserted that since the introduction of the maternity allowance the fees of medical men have increased to such an extent as to annex a very substantial portion of that allowance. Why should these men escape taxation ? It is almost impossible to differentiate between what are, and what are not, war-time' profits. T7nder this, clause solicitors, barristers, and doctors, together with a whole army of other persons who can afford to pay taxation just as well as can some 'of the friends of Senator Fairbairn - some of the big squatters of this country - will be exempt from taxation. It is very commonly stated that men who possess no property whatever are making huge profits in Australia, and authorities like John Stuart Mill and Adam Smith have erroneously laid it down that such persons ought to be called upon to pay taxation. The Bill will interfere' with. industry all along the line, it will nob create any fresh avenues of employment, and it seeks to take from people something they have earned, arid to .use it for the benefit of the community. As the Government possesses a substantial working majority in this Chamber the passing of the Bill is a foregone conclusion.
- The honorable senator makes it a foregone conclusion. He denounces the measure as an inequitable one, and yet he supports it.

- Honorable senators upon this side of the chamber are in a minority. Of themselves they can do nothing. But if honorable senators opposite who are opposed to the Bill will act in .accordance with their convictions, the measure may not pass in its present form. I repeat that there is no justification for exempting solicitors and doctors from the operation of this Bill. It is also proposed to exempt profits arising from gold-mining operations. ' Why should that be done if we tax the profits arising from mining wolfram, molybdenite, scheelite, and tungsten ?
- Why did the honorable senator tell the people that the purchasing power of a sovereign is only 12s now as 'compared with its purchasing power in the pre-war period ?

- The proposal to> exempt profits arising from gold-mining, while taxing profits accruing from the mining of minerals, seems to me to be so unfair that even honorable senators opposite will not approve of it. I shall support the amendment of Senator Gardiner. I am entirely opposed, to exemptions, and I only regret that he has not moved for the elimination of all exemptions."
. - It is curious to note the perverted logic that is being employed in the discussion of this Bill.
- The Vice-President of the Executive Council (Senator Millen) says that the honorable senator's logic is not too good.

- He may say that, but I think that in private he entertains a different opinion of the whole matter, just as does the Treasurer (Sir John Forrest). It seems to me that we have been making mists through which to see less clearly, because honorable senators are supporting a measure which embodies an inherently vicious principle. I, too, will agree to to be elimination of all exemptions, if only profits directly traceable to war conditions are to be taxed.
- That is the idea.

- It was acknowledged by the Vice-President of the Executive Council last night th,at it is intended to tax profits earned during a certain arbitrary period called the war-time period, irrespective of whether those profits can be traced to war conditions or not. Such a principle is inherently vicious. My attitude towards the amendment is quite different from that of Senator Pratten. He regards it as unfair, but wishes to serve out the misery and inequity all round.

- Senator Pratten sees elements of grave danger in this Bill, and in this clause, yet he is willing to. accept an amendment so sweeping in its character as to make the inequitable principle of the measure of general application. He would drag all industries' into the whirlpool- I am opposed to the principle embodied in the Bill, and I therefore take up another attitude. I regard every industry that is saved from the operation of the Bill as something gained.
- " A brand plucked from the burning."

- Exactly. So far from objecting to the exemptions already provided for, I have it in contemplation, if possible, to increase the list before the Bill leaves Committee. Nothing, therefore, will induce me to support Senator Gardiner's amendment.

speech.para: It seems to have been forgotten that no profit-earning industry in the Common wealth will escape taxation. The industries which derive their profits from war conditions, in common with all other industries, will be subject to the provisions of the Income Tax Acts. To my great astonishment, the Vice-President of the Executive Council, despite the mental acuteness with which we are all prepared to credit him, denied last night that from the early stages of the discussion of this matter -tine idea was that there should be taxation of war prdfits, and not of wartime profits.

talk.start.para: - I stated that the original idea in the minds of most people was a war-profits tax.

- With great deference to the honorable senator, I say that the idea in the minds of most people now is that the measure to be passed is one for the taxation of profits directly attributable to war conditions. In a letter appearing in this morning's Argus, under the heading "War Profits Tax," the writer quotes Mr. Groom. He has a grievance, in common with every one who is protesting against this strange measure. He mentions that at page 1702 of Hansard for this session, Mr. Groom is reported as having said -

quote.para: Our object is to make it clear that only wartime excess profits shall be liable.

talk.start.para: - " War-time."

- Yes, but "excess " profits. My contention is that many enterprises that materialized before and since the beginning of the war have no pre-war standard of profits, or any profit directly derivable from war conditions, and yet they will be taxed under this measure. I do not suppose that my protests will be very effective. I did not anticipate that they would, but I must make them heard. I welcome any opportunity which the close investigation of the various clauses of this Bill will give honorable senators to show the public that they are not insensible to the injustices which will almost inevitably be inflicted by its instrumentality. I am not going to adopt the attitude adopted by Senator Gardiner, who says that the measure may be wrong or right, but whether wrong or right, everything must be swept into it. I am sorry that such a clear reasoner as Senator Pratten should, perhaps in sheer desperation, have allied himself with Senator Gardiner in this matter.
- The honorable senator does not believe in sweeping all in when it is a matter of money, but he does when it is a matter of men.

- I believe in sweeping everything in that can be shown to be directly attributable to the conditions set up by the war. I believe in taking that money to meet war expenditure. In respect of such profits, I am not in favour of any exemptions. - Senator Gardiner. - Yet the honorable senator is going to vote for exemptions.
- Because this is not a measure for the taxation of profits directly attributable to war conditions. Does Senator Gardiner impugn the logic of my attitude?
- I fail to see it.

- There are none so blind as those who care not to see. I believe that the trouble in which we have involved ourselves is due to the attempt to prove the exploitation of the people by men who are benefiting from war conditions. There may be substantial profits made which are directly traceable to war conditions, and if we had adhered carefully to our original intention to secure those profits, we might have readily succeeded in doing so, and at the same time have been guiltless of inflicting any injustice upon the producers of the Commonwealth. But we have been led astray in connexion with the matter, and now, because of some imagined difficulties we are losing ourselves in a wandering maze.
- Let the honorable senator get us out of it.

- I shall get honorable senators out of it if they will follow me. Senator Gardiner must see that if we desired to levy on profits derivable or derived from war conditions, it would be logical to make every producing industry in Australia pay. But if we are not going to adhere strictly to that principle, and if, on the contrary, we are to legislate in terms of expediency, and along the lines of least resistance, not of the taxpayer, but of the legislator, we shall inflict very grave injustice. To show the iniquity incidental to the operation of this clause, Senator Pratten has pointed out that the production of one metal will be exempt, whilst the production of another will be brought under the operation of the Bill.

speech.para: In some respects it may be said that the agriculturist will be worse off ' than the miner under the Bill. The products of the agriculturist are perishable, and in some cases even where they are kept in cold storage they deteriorate. They are a wasting asset as perishable products, but the agriculturist has always his land which, subject to the vicissitudes of the seasons, is always productive. He is in that respect better off than the miner. Although the ore extracted from a mine will not deteriorate for many years, since there are only some very rare ores that become impaired in .value by oxidization, it has to be remembered that the mine is a wasting asset. The life of any mine is an ascertainable period, and there is no endless vista of production in the case of a mineral deposit. Yet it is proposed to allow some mine owners to escape this tax, and to make others pay. It is proposed to allow agriculturists, whose asset - the land - never wastes, to escape.

talk.start.para: - My amendment would include the agriculturists.

- I am aware of that. It would include them in what I regard as one common ruin. My attitude is that of salvage and rescue, while that of Senator Gardiner is wholesale destruction. And I am sorry that such a level-headed man as Senator Pratten should have been induced to support him. I shall vote against the amendment, and I hope that I have made plain to honorable senators its pernicious character. I have drafted an amendment to be submitted later on, which will deal with this situation, but I have come to the conclusion that the measure is so designated and so drafted-
- The. honorable senator will not be in order in discussing the whole measure on this clause.

- I shall content myself with saying that this clause and the proposed amendment of it, considered in themselves, are essentially vicious, and in that respect partake only of the character of the whole measure.

speech.para: Senator GARDINER (New South Wales) [2.431-1 intend to try and reconcile the logical position of Senator Bakhap and my own. The honorable senator is opposed to tke whole Bill. He considers that it is inequitable, and is not therefore prepared to bring any business under it. I am dealing with the particular clause now before the Committee, and it is my purpose, if possible, to make that clause equitable. I believe that the. farmer who secures war-time excess profits from his crop, should be called Upon to pay this taxation as well as the miller who secures war-time excess profits by grinding it into flour.

talk.start.para: - What is the honorable senator's distinction between profits and prices?

- Senator Guthrie might put a big price upon himself, but it would not be profitable for any person to purchase him at that price. This Bill deals with excess profits made during the war period. I want to put this proposition fairly. Senator Bakhap pointed out that gold, particularly in the mines, is a diminishing quantity, as a company uses up its principal in producing profits from the mine. But does not the same principle apply to coal 1 And yet, under this Bill the coal-mining industry will have to pay the tax.
- But the price for coal varies, and that is not the case with gold.
- There may be a varying price for coal, but if the purchasing power of the sovereign, as a. standard of value, varies, then there must be a varying price for gold also.
- No, because gold depreciates while other values appreciate.

- In that case, then, there will be less to pay in respect of the gold-mining industry. The Government proposal is to tax the coalmining industry and exempt the rich gold companies which produce this mineral at a great profit.
- Is that profit owing to the war?
- No. It is due to the fact that the wealthy companies, particularly, have been given a monopoly to reap profits, and Western Australian legislators compel the taxpayers of that State to pay.
- The Western Australian mines are the only gold mining companies in Australia that have to pay taxation on their dividends.

- And if one looks at the share list, will find that the Government of Western Australia are allowing foreign shareholders to get the full benefit of the profits from the mines, while the miners themselves work long hours and under harsh conditions for a very small wage indeed.
- They are the highest paid miners in Australia.
- The belief I hold is that no miners are paid sufficiently.
- You know very little about mining.
- I suppose if I knew half as much as the honorable senator imagines he knows, I would probably be better informed than all the rest of the world put together.
- WelL I do know something about mining.
- Yes; because the honorable senator is a good underground engineer.
- I am not half as proficient as you are.
- No doubt, because rats are supposed to be good miners.
- Order ! These recriminations across the Chamber are distinctly out of order.
- I want to approach this question fairly. Gold is Crown metal. Who owns it?
- Those who get it. 8

- It is reserved to the Crown, and yet, under this proposal, the wealthy mining companies are to be permitted to take Crown gold, or, if we regard the Crown as representing the people, to take our gold, and- we are not going to ask them to pay any taxation on their war-time profits. If these mining companies are nob making profits, they will not be taxed. It is not the gold-miner, but the rich gold mine-owners, who will be affected by my amendment.
- But the honorable senator knows there are no excess profits on gold mining.

- Then the companies will not be taxed. In my opinion, the Bill is inequitable. I do not believe that it is possible to frame any system of taxation that will not bear more unjustly upon one section of the people than another, unless it be the system advocated by Senator Grant so frequently. Senator Bakhap is prepared to exempt certain industries because he believes the Bill to be inequitable. I want to include all industries that are making war-time profits, because I think that all profits should be taxed. If when the measure reaches the third-reading stage, it is not satisfactory to me, I shall certainly adopt a different attitude. I was anxious to see it get into Committee in. the hope that we would be able to put it into an equitable shape. Senator Bakhap) after all, is only making a pretence of opposition, and whenever he sees a chance of escaping, he gets behind the Government. I want to improve the Bill if it is a bad measure. Government supporters are evidently' of that opinion, judging by the criticism it received at their hands, scarcely one member on the Ministerial side having a word to say in favour of it, either here or in another place. If the measure is not improved it will also receive condemnation at the hands of the people.

speech.para: What excuse is there for exempting any section of businesses which have made excess profits during war time? Senator Bakhap says that such concerns will pay income tax, bub will not all those who are included under this measure also be called upon tq pay income tax? At the best this Bill is an expedient, and though I have no doubt Senator Millen will declare that I indorsed its principle in regard to a former measure, I want to say that, so far as this clause is concerned, I never- intend to support any war-time taxation measure that proposes to deal with one industrial section in a manner different from any other. I hold that all industries making profits during war-time should pay this form of taxation. Let us take butter factories or bacon-curing establishments as an illustration. With their plants they can supply the local town with electricity, but because their main business is the handling of produce, they will escape taxation on the profits they may make upon any other business.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1910; LP from 1913; NAT from 1917
talker.name: MILLEN, Edward
Senator MILLEN

talk.start.para: - No. They will only get exemption to the extent that they make their profits out of the exempted portion of the industry.

- I am glad to have this assurance, because I was under the impression that the amendment introduced by the Minister -was to the effect I have indicated. Where the main part of such company's business is the handling of produce, and where they supply electric light as a by-product, I believe they will be exempt. But suppose the Minister is right, why should a co-operative concern, producing bacon for profit, be exempt from the operation of this tax, whilst a proprietary business competing with that co-operative enterprise would be called upon to pay an excess war-time profits tax?
- Hear, hearl

- I submitted my amendment because, unlike Senator Bakhap, I feel utterly incompetent to hold the balance evenly, and distinguish between people who deserve to be exempt, and people who do not deserve to be exempt. It is not fair to allow any concern to get an advantage over its rival.
- Hear, hear !

- Let us consider the position of. two big business enterprises. Let us suppose that one business, by careful management, had two years of big profits to its credit, in 1912 and 1913, and that another, and a growing business, in 1912 and 1913, by special, efforts against its rival, reaped its reward in 1915 and 1916. What would be the result under this Bill? The growing business would have to pay a tax on its profits over and above the profits of the previous two years, whereas the other business would escape because of its prewar standard, and, possibly, it would, drive its -rival out of business.
- It would not drive its competitor out if the latter were making a profit.

- The older business might, in such circumstances, have such an advantage that its rival might be compelled to get out of the business,- but if b.oth companies were taxed equally on their war-time profits, one business concern would not have an advantage over the other. It is altogether unfair to distinguish between businesses making profits, and as I do not feel competent to judge between industries that should be exempt and those that should not, I have submitted my amendment to include all industries making a profit.
- Senator Grant says that it is not. comprehensive enough.

- If the Committee decides against me I will take up the attitude adopted by Senator Bakhap, and try to exempt from the provisions of the Bill as many industries as possible, because, I maintain, we cannot hold the balance evenly between industries. We cannot and I am not going to make an attempt. I submit the amendment, which may be too sweeping for some honorable senators. As regards gold mines, it will be the rich companies which will be affected. I have no doubt that the gold -mil. vng companies in Western Australia will always have sufficient influence with the Government to secure exemption from just taxation which this Parliament should impose upon them.
