talk.start.para: . - Before lunch, Senator Fairbairn brought, up a case of companies which, though legally and technically cooperative companies, had really become proprietary companies, because of the absorption by one or two individuals of the major portion of the shares. I must admit that the case has appealed to me very strongly. No one desires to allow a company or a few individuals to get an advantage denied to Weir competitors merely because they are sailing under false colours. I ask the honorable senator, therefore, to refrain from submitting his amendment now in order to give me an opportunity of seeing how far the case he cited may be provided for by an amendment of the definition clause. The notice given to me by the honorable senator has been too brief to permit me to consult the draftsmen and the Treasurer (Sir John Forrest), but I will see that an opportunity is provided for him to recommit the definition clause should he wish to press the matter on the attention of the Senate at a later period.

. - I have much pleasure in falling in with the wish of the Minister, and I therefore ask leave to withdraw my amendment. T have no desire to interfere with bond fide co-operative companies. It is only the bogus concerns which my amendment is aimed at.
- There is nothing before the Chair at present, and therefore the honorable senator has simply to refrain from moving the amendment.
.- I move -

quote.para: That sub-clause 1, paragraph b,. be amended by inserting after the word "Australia" the following words :-[-" so far as regards the manufacture, preparation, or wholesale distribution of foodstuffs, the produce of Australia."

speech.para: The effect of the amendment will be to prevent the situation arising which Senator Gardiner referred to a little while ago. Where a company is making profits by carrying on two operations, it will insure that the only profits exempted from the tax will be those which were earned by the manufacture, preparation, or wholesale distribution of foodstuffs, the produce of Australia.

talk.start.para: . - I have an amendment to move in connexion with the business of co-operative societies, and I shall be very glad indeed if the Minister will allow the matter to stand over till Tuesday with the ' other matter he referred to in connexion with. Senator Fairbairn's proposed amendment, because by that time I may be in a position to give him several specific instances. It will help, I believe, in the better moulding of the clause.

. - I have every wish to meet the honorable senator, but I doubt if .the amendment of which he has given notice is at all in conformity with the case indicated by Senator Fairbairn. While it is possible to meet that case by an amendment of the definition clause, I do not think it will be possible to meet the case indicated by Senator Pratten's amendment in that way. Therefore, I suggest, unless he has any other objection, that he should proceed with the amendment now, because I do not wish to recommit the whole Bill. By recommitting the definition clause, it will give Senator Fairbairn an opportunity of reconsidering the matter he has raised, but I do not think it will give Senator Pratten a similar opportunity for dealing with the matter he raises in his amendment.
- We are not likely to have the whole of the Bill put through before 4 o'clock.
- I am not without hope.

.- I move - That the following new paragraph be inserted: - " (a) any insurance or trading company of a co-operative nature, whose return in profits to its shareholders or members is limited by its constitution to not more than 10 per centum per annum."

speech.para: All over Australia there are very many co-operative societies which are outside of the particular co-operative societies exempted by the Bill. These societies are buying and selling for their members, and are not making profits in the ordinary acceptation of the term. Their so-called profits are really savings for the members.

talk.start.para: - Yes; but there are other kinds of co-operative societies.

- There are, I admit, kinds of co-operative societies which cannot be distinguished essentially from a business which is merely carried on for profit or for loss. There has been some development of co-operation right through Australia in connexion with various bodies. Yesterday, I referred to the cooperative trading companies in Newcastle, Lithgow, Wollongong, and Sydney. I Have a knowledge of these companies in my own State, and I can sav that they do not make profits in the ordinary acceptation of the term. The dividends are bounded, in some cases, by a 5 per cent, maximum in other cases by an 8 per cent, maximum, and, in other cases, by a 10 per cent, maximum.
- And their "shares are put on the market.

- No ; I am not referring to those companies whose shares are put on the market. I am alluding to those companies whose directors are very often union officials. The secretary of a company is often a union official, and the directors, too, are union officials. They are all working for nothing, because they want to save money for those whom they supply, and who are members of the company, and wish to-cut out the middleman. The true principle of co-operation, I take it i is an effort on the part of people who come together to cut out unnecessary profits which otherwise they would have to pay. The profits axe only profits in name. They are distributed from time to time amongst those purchasers or suppliers of the company with whom they do business. I would point out to the Minister (Senator Millen) that to bring companies of this sort under the provisions of the Bill, and to take, in some cases, in the future, 75 per cent, of the money they save by co-operation, is a wrong principle. We know that in- England co-operation is growing, and that many societies are on the same basis. I .can definitely say that companies of this sort do not come under the excess profits tax at Home, and I do not think that this Committee should impose a tax upon the companies in Australia. We would be going much too far if we did. While I see very great difficulties in differentiating up to- a fine point between those companies which are essentially co-operative, and those companies which are out to trade for a profit, this Bill should in this matter, and I hope will, give very large powers to the Commissioner of Taxation. These wide powers will be subject to an appeal to the Board of Referees. If there is a dispute as to whether companies of this sort ought to pay or not, the Board of Referees will decide. But if we do not get a provision of this sort inserted to govern the instances of bond fide growing co-operative movements, they must be taxed. There will be no option, because they are not exempted. It will put back co-operation for perhaps a decade. I do not think that any one of us desires to do that, because, after all, co-operation and co-partnership may be the solution of our future troubles. I should be very sorry indeed to see the Commissioner tax savings which otherwise would go back to the purchasers of the goods, or the supporters of the companies or ' societies. I ask the Committee most earnestly to consider this aspect, and see whether some provision cannot be devised, if my amendment is hot particularly acceptable to the majority, whereby we shall not give a set-back to the whole principle of co-operation. Unless some clause is- inserted which will cover bond fide societies, there will be a weakness in the Bill, and we shall live to rue and regret it. If co-operative societies, run in the country in connexion with primary products, are to be exempted, I cannot see why other societies cannot be exempted that are being run in the same bond fide manner to deal with other goods. For the sake of this very m.uteh wanted principle of cooperation in Australia, for the sake of the elimination of the middleman and two or three unnecessary profits, I urge that we should encourage rather than discourage such movements as this.

. - On the face of it, Senator Pratten's proposal would appear to exclude from the Bill a company which does not pay its shareholders more th,an 10 per cent. But if it makes only 10 per cent, profit it is excluded now. Therefore, the honorable senator is proposing to keep out of the Bill some company which is making more than 10 per cent. Honorable senators will find that the amendment provides for the exemption, of any insurance or trading company of a co-operative nature whose return in profits to its shareholders is limited by 10 per cent. This does not mean that it has not made more than 10 per cent., but that it has not distributed more than 10 per cent.
- The balance is the saving returned to the shareholders.

- If the company does not make more than 10 per cent, it is exempted under the Bill now, because it can take 10 per cent, as it's pre-war standard. Therefore, either the amendment is sucplusage, or Senator Pratten invites us to say that companies making more than 10 per cent, shall be exempt; the only essential Condition being that they do not distribute more than 10 per cent, of their profits. But there are plenty of ways by which a company making 20 per cent, or 30 per cent, can secure those profits quite comfortably to those interested in it, whilst only returning 10 per cent, to its shareholders. I leave it to the Committee to say whether a company making anything up to 50 per cent, shall be exempted merely because it only distributes 10 per cent, to its shareholders.
- Will you assure the Committee that the so-called profits, or savings, as I prefer to call them, which are returned to the purchasers or policy holders, will not be taxed ?

- This proposal was not put up in the interests of those who do business with the company. It is put up in the interests of the company itself, because it speaks' of the company, and not of those who deal with it. This would cover the case of a company started, as has been done in New South Wales, in consequence of the passage of the Workmen's Compensation Act. A number of people with trade interests in common have formed a company. They are co-operating; they are shareholders in the company, and do the insurance business within the trade with which they are associated; but there are many people outside them who are not shareholders but also do business with them. Any profits that are made may be returned as bonuses, or they may not. That rests with the company. But the articles of association' provide for a limit of, say, 10 per cent, to be paid in dividends. If the company makes 40 per cent, or 50 per cent., the extra profit will go into those hidden reserves which enable the company to extend its operations, and, therefore, represents savings or profits that ought legitimately to be taxed.

. - I referred principally to bond fide co-operative distributing companies. But co-operative companies have been formed in New South Wales by various associations for the purpose of cooperating together, particularly in regard to employers' liability insurance. Those societies put up a certain amount of capital. In their articles of association they limit the interest on that capital to 10 per cent. They are working the -business on a cost of about 10 per cent. Whereas the ordinary accident company as we see it in Melbourne or Sydney spends about 30 per cent, of the premiums, these cooperative societies spend about 10 per cent, of the premiums. At the end of the year they bring down a balance-sheet showing a so-called profit of so much, and the whole of that profit over and above the 10 per cent, paid to the shareholders is given back to the policy-holders in the company the next year. If a butcher, baker, or candlestick maker joins the company, and gets his accident insurance cheaper thereby, there -is an accretion to his income to a corresponding extent upon which he will pay income tax. But if the Government say under this Bill that in the future no one may co-operate for a purpose of that sort, because if they do the Government will take 75 per cent, of the savings they make, they will simply squash these societies.
- No; the company will charge more reasonable premiums, and, therefore, have less to distribute.
- Surely the honorable senator does not want to upset the procedure of the whole .of the business world while this Bill is in operation.
- You have done that now by these co-operative companies being able to do for 20 per cent, what you say the proprietary companies used to do for 50 per cent.

- I know a great deal about these cases. Is the Committee determined to take the savings made by co-operation throughout Australia? If it is, it .ought to say so, and not exclude even the primary producer. If honorable senators take that attitude they stand convicted as opponents of cooperation in any shape or form. This would be very unjust1 in the case that Senator Millen has mentioned, if the Income Tax Commissioner, in his sometimes ruthless and relentless way, puts the collection of money before equity. Co-operative companies, such as I have mentioned, if they are bond fide, and the shareholders cannot get at any time more than 10 per cent., and if all the profits of one year are returned to its supporters in' the following year, are really not making a profit at all. They represent bond fide co-operation. Profit is what the investors in a company get or have in reserve. This is a matter which does not affect the reserves of a company. The whole question is whether the savings of any co-operative company, present or future, in Australia, shall be subject to excess tax.

. - The company Senator Pratten refers to is not co-operative at all, but proprietary. A number of people having their own insurance to do, form themselves into a company. The-" take their own insurance business to that company, but they also take business from any member of the public. That is no more entitled to be called a co-operative company than any other proprietary company which, doing its own business, also does business with the general public. Senator PRATTEN (New South Wales) [3.25].- Senator Milieu's statement is incorrect. The company does not do business with any member of the public. It confines itself to its own class and its own trade. ,
- Does it take business only from those who have an interest in its share capital?
- It takes business only from those associated with the same class of industry.
- Yes, but not shareholders in that company.

- That raises another point. Will the Vice-President of the Executive Council agree to an exemption in favour of companies which do business only amongst their own shareholders 1 Will he exempt companies where two-thirds of the business is of that character the same as in -the primary industries ?
- No; this Bill does not exempt co-operative companies.

- It exempts primary co-operative companies. It has been pointed out that this is an injustice as against proprietary and privately owned companies. I beg the Vice-President of the Executive Council to consider this case, and allow me to bring some evidence in regard to these particular companies - I have it partially collected now - so that no injustice shall be inflicted.

. - In the consideration of the Insurance Bill some time ago, a matter cropped up similar to that which Senator Pratten has brought forward. It appears to me that if these companies expended the money in the way of soliciting trade, they would escape this taxation. But because they do not, but return it to their shareholders, they are , to be penalized. The so much eulogized thrift is to be fined. If a company eliminates expenses, and returns the money to those who have subscribed it, it is to be punished.
- What the company referred to does is like what is done by a " great many people who give you coupons with your purchases, but they are nob cooperative.

- The Minister will have to define " co-operation." If all the business men of Melbourne combined to do their own fire insurance . business amongst' themselves, and cut out the expenses of agencies and so forth incurred by proprietary insurance companies, they would not be a co-operative society, according to Senator Millen. I contend that if they limit the business to themselves, co-operate amongst themselves, and return the savings to themselves, they are to all intents and purposes cooperators.
- If they returned the savings before the end of the year it would not be a profit.
- They do not make them until the end of the year.
- Then if the savings are returned before the 31st December, they are legitimate, but if they are held over until the 2nd January they constitute a crime. Is that the position the Minister takes up?
- What I say is that these companies are not co-operative companies in the true sense of the word.
- Will the Vice-President of the Executive. Council explain what he means by " the true sense of the word"?
- There are companies which are made up of the persons who provide them with their business, and who are also shareholders in their capital.

- In a co-operative company a portion of its shares may be held by merchants and storekeepers, who perhaps deal with a cheese and butter factory. In such a company the majority of the shares will probably be in the hands of those persons who supply milk to that factory. According to the reasoning of the Vice-President of the Executive Council, that portion of the profits of the company which is distributed amongst the merchants and storekeepers who provided it with the capital with which to start operations, should be exempt from taxation, while that portion which is distributed amongst, those who supply the factory with milk should be taxable. I cannot understand how the Vice-President of the Executive Council can argue that such a company is not a co-operative company. It represents a co-operation cf effort for a definite purpose, that purpose being the conferring of a mutual benefit.
- Then the man who buys anything, ,and the .individual who sells it, may be said to. co-operate for their mutual benefit.

- I differ from the honorable senator. The individual who assists another to convert something into an article which is useful is a co-operator in the truest sense of the word. Take the case of a number of butchers in Adelaide, who have associated themselves together as an accident insurance society. That society covenanted to cover risks in connexion with the butchering trade. -Its members are co-operators. They are trading, not in the sense of manufacturing something, but they are trading cooperatively. Their profits are distributed amongst themselves. So long as the profits in a company are limited to the persons within that company, I say that those persons ,are co-operators. The position of a proprietary company is very different. Its business is carried on for the benefit of its owner or owners. I think that Senator Pratten has made out a very good case for his amendment.' We ought to encourage, rather than discourage, groups of individuals to band themselves together for the purpose of establishing accident insurance funds, covering fire insurance risks, and generally carrying the burdens that are associated with such institutions.
- The trouble is that we cannot make them carry the burdens.

- That is because the number of persons covered by them is so small. My honorable friend may argue that, because the Adelaide Co-operative Society could not carry the burden imposed upon it in the early stages of its existence-
- There were only a dozen people in it then.
- That society could not. then carry the burden that it is carrying to-day, when there are a thousand persons interested in it.
- Elder, Smith, and Company occupy a similar position.

- No. I can purchase the shares of Elder, Smith, and Company in the open market, but I cannot purchase the shares of the Adelaide Co-operative Society there. I hope that the amendment will be pressed.

speech.para: Senator PRATTEN (New South Wales) withdraw my amendment with a view to substituting for it another amendment which may prove more acceptable to honorable senators.

quote.para: That the following new paragraph be inserted' : - " (fl) any company of a co-operative nature, consisting of persons who are providing the business of the company and also providing its capital, . whose return in profits to its shareholders or members is limited by its constitution to not more than 10 per cent, per annum."

talk.start.para: - That will take in half the banks.
- It is altogether too wide.

.- It has occurred .to me that an anomaly may arise in dealing with co-operative societies, inasmuch as the various State Acts do not all provide for the registration of these societies in the same way. If I remember aright, the Victorian Act provides that cooperative societies must be registered under the Friendly Societies Act. If that be so, these societies in Victoria will be exempt from the operation of titis Bill, but in States in which the Act does not provide for their registration under the Friendly Societies Act, they will be liable to the tax.

. - Senator Guy has raised the question of the position of co-operative societies which are not registered under the Friendly Societies Act. I would point out to him that, under this Bill, these societies occupy exactly the same position irrespective of whether they are registered or not. The only societies which will be exempt from its operation are those which are not carried on for the purpose of profit or gain.

talk.start.para: - Order! The Committee has just rejected an amendment after paragraph /, so that the honorable senator is too late.
.- I move-

quote.para: That after paragraph / the following new paragraph be inserted: - " and (g) businesses commenced since the fourth day of August, One thousand nine hundred and fourteen, for the. purpose of mining wolfram, molybdenite, tungsten, scheelite, or any other rare metal used in the manufacture of munitions of war, if the output of -the mine is disposed of to the Imperial Government."

speech.para: I do not think I need say much to commend this amendment to honorable senators. The mines are conducted in a small way, chiefly by working men. Their products are absolutely necessary for the prosecution of the war, and they are being sold to the British Government at the very low price of 360 per ton. In America, 600 per ton is paid for these metals.

talk.start.para: - The Government are prepared to accept this amendment.

. - As Senator Millen has mentioned that the Government are prepared to accept the amendment, I shall not encroach upon the time of the Committee further than to say that I am heartily in favour of Senator Fairbairn's proposal.
, - There seems to me to be a redundancy in the terms of the amendment. I am aware of only two tungsten ores, namely, wolfram and scheelite.
- And molybdenite is mentioned.

- Molybdenite is not an ore of tungsten, but an ore of the metal molybdenum, lb is a redundancy to mention tungsten as an independent ore. To the best of my knowledge, tungsten ores are obtained in two forms - tungsten of iron, which is wolfram; and tungsten of lime, which is scheelite. I respectfully suggest to Senator Fairbairn that as the two commercial sources of tungsten are mentioned in his amendment, the use of the word "tungsten," in addition, is a redundancy. Seeing that the Government have so readily accepted this amendment, I should like to ask: What about tin? It is a metal absolutely essential to the prosecution of the war, and in respect of which it cannot be shown that the average price during the war period has been greater .than the price during the three years prior to the war.

. - I am in favour of the amendment. I believe Senator Fairbairn is aiming in the right direction; still I direct attention to the fact that industries are established for the production of other metals, which are quite as important as the industries sought to be protected by the amendment. At the present time, there is an absence of barytes in Australia. We have the metal in the* Commonwealth, but we are importing it. It has been discovered as the result of a recent exploration, is mined, and brought long distances to market. Only to-day I heard that deposits have been found in Victoria. Paper is becoming scarce, and I may inform honorable senators that barium is used for the purpose of perfecting the surface of printing paper.
- Also in the manufacture of paints.
- Also in connexion with white leads, which are very scarce. It would appear that one class of industry is to be exempt, and others equally important and necessary are to be taxed.
- The products of one class are being sold to the Imperial authorities at half the world's price.

- The Minister apparently believes that if the product of an industry is sold at half price, there is some virtue in it ; but if it merely supplies a public need, it should be taxed. Another industry which might be mentioned is one exploiting the manufacture of sulphate of lime, gypsum, for the purpose of producing plaster of Paris, which we have been importing largely. I know of another case, where manganese is being exploited to be used with other substances to produce true crockery ware. An honorable senator has referred to the scarcity of fire-bricks, but I know of splendid deposits of pure silicate of alumina which makes the best of fire-bricks. If people invest in these industries to-day, because a peculiarly advantageous opportunity is afforded at this time to give them a start, they are to be penalized under this measure, whilst the production of the metals referred to in Senator Fairbairn 's amendment is to be exempt. I know that potash salts imported in a manufactured form from Germany can be obtained in the Commonwealth. It is strange that when we have a chemical research association under the sheltering wing of the Federal Government, and their researches have disclosed the possibility of the establishment of industries of practical benefit to Australia, honorable senators on this side are apparently prepared to penalize their establishment. There is not one of the substances I have referred to the production of which would not be a real public utility, and involve the employment of many persons.
- They are allowed 10 per cent, profit before they are liable to this taxation.

- The honorable senator should be aware that very large expense is involved in the establishment of new industries of this kind. Expensive machinery has to be installed, and in many cases it is not long-lived; whilst there must be a considerable period of unprofitable preliminary work. Ten per cent., in the circumstances, is not a reasonable reward for the establishment of such industries. It is unfair that when an attempt is made to establish them it should be crippled by taxation of this kind. There seems to be a determination to allow outsiders to benefit at the expense of Australians. I do not want to see the ores that I have mentioned eliminated, and I hope the amendment will be extended to include them. I could occupy the Committee for a considerable time in showing where there are openings for such enterprises, and how the clause will make them impracticable. For instance, I know that deposits of slate for roofing purposes - an article which is urgently required to-day - could be worked profitably were it not for the fact that any profit obtained from that enterprise would come within the scope of this measure, and be taxed to the extent of 75 per cent. This matter is too important to be allowed to pass without a protest. I hope the Minister will report progress, so as to allow the Committee to discuss this question fully.

. - The longer the discussion proceeds the greater appear to be the difficulties, and the gathering doubt in the minds of honorable senators as to the justice of allowing any exemption at all. I am convinced I was right in voting for Senator Gardiner's amendment to sweep away all exemptions. If it is fair to exempt the metals mentioned by Senator Fairbairn, would it not also be fair to exempt other metals which are necessary for the prosecution of this war?
- Metals which are being sold at less than the market value?

- It would depend largely on what is regarded as market value. Zinc may be quoted as a very important constituent,' largely used in the manufacture of munitions. Copper, and lead to some extent, are also so used.
- Would you exempt copper?
- The interjection from the honorable senator confirms what I have said, that once we start making exemptions we do not know where to' stop.
- We shall be perpetrating a greater injustice if we allow no exemptions.

- The British Government have commandeered all our metals, including those mentioned in the amendment, and it is probable that the producers of these metals would have been able to obtain a higher price for them but for the action by the British Government.
- That is practically admitted by the fact that prices have been fixed in many instances.
- Yes; to some extent the producers are not getting the price they would have obtained in the world's open market.
- Then, the same may be said of wool, so would you exempt the pastoral industry as well?

- I would exempt none. That is the difference between my attitude and Senator Fairbairn's. I have listened very carefully , to all that has been said on this subject, and I am convinced that those who voted against exemptions took the right course, and that we are only getting deeper into the mire by attempting to widen the scope of the exemptions.
- The honorable senator would have done right if he had assisted in modelling the measure so as to make it a purely war profits tax.

- If Senator Fairbairn thinks it fair to exempt the metals he has mentioned, how can he refuse to exempt other base metals, which, perhaps, although not to the same extent, are affected by the measure ? I voted against any exemptions, not excepting even gold, but the Committee has decided to exempt certain industries, and I now intend to support Senator Bakhap's proposal to exempt other base metals in addition to those mentioned by Senator Fairbairn. In these circumstances, we' shall be doing the right tiling if, at the recommittal stage, we decide to exempt all metals.

. - While I am heartily in accord with the amendment moved by Senator Fairbairn, I want to point out that, even as a measure affording relief, it discloses once more, in all its nakedness, the principle of inequity, against which I have so frequently protested during the discussion on this Bill, which, I hope, will not pass in its present form. Wolfram mines and those enterprises engaged in the output of molybdenite, which have commenced operations since the 4th August, 1914, will be exempted by Senator Fairbairn's amendment. So far, so good. 'But what about mines that were established, capitalized, and were in process of development before the 4th August, 1914, and which have only commenced to be remunerative during the war period ? Are these to bear the brunt of taxation, while industries established since, the 4th August obtain relief? Surely the Committee will take this matter into consideration. I am not a wolfram miner, and I have no interest in wolfram. I am a tin miner, and possess certain tin leases, the operations of which, however, will not be affected by this measure at all, for the simple reason that they are only small leases, and the output is not likely to be such as to get outside the zone of protection afforded by the financial exemptions. But I am concerned with the position occupied by many old friends of mine, who, after a mining life full of vicissitudes, in the evening of their days, discovered wolfram deposits shortly prior to the outbreak of war, and who have made these properties productive during the war. These men will not secure the benefit of this exemption, whereas any mining enterprise dealing with the deposits of ores mentioned in Senator Fairbairn's amendment will be relieved. The thing is manifestly incompatible. We shall have to give relief to industries of a special character, whether they were established before the war period or since the outbreak of the war, and relief must also be given to industries which are not deriving any benefit from any increase in the market price for their products, or we shall stand charged before the people of Australia with being a most inept set of legislators, ready to adopt every legislative expedient, but who will not face the problem of establishing the principle of equity in relation to taxation proposals. The public anticipated a War Profits Bill which would tax all profits legitimately traceable to war conditions. The people did not expect anything else, because anything else in equity they could not demand, seeing that profits gained from any other cause would be levied upon under the income tax. I ask Senator Fairbairn to use his undoubted influence with the Ministry to secure an extension of the principle contained in his amendment, for he alone seems to have any influence in regard to suggested amendments.
. - I am not aware that I have any great influence with the Minister.
- It was the soundness of your amendment that appealed to me.

- I have no interest in these metals. In fact, I hardly know their names. Naturally, I would like to oblige Senator Bakhap, but he must admit that I am plucking a few brands from the burning, and if, later on, I can assist him to persuade the Government to consent to some reasonable request, I shall be happy to do so.
- Do it now. Ask the Minister if it is not a reasonable request.
. - I should like to add my voice to that of Senator Bakhap in the direction of asking the Minister to accept the amendment.
- Senator Bakhap has not asked me to do anything.
- I asked the Minister to declare himself.
- Senator Bakhap asked Senator Fairbairn to ask me to do something.
- Previously to that you declined.

- If the argument holds good that these metals have been commandeered for the British Government at half price, and that they are essential to the production of munitions of war, the more of them we can produce just now,' irrespective of the age of the companies, the better.

. - I add my voice to Senator Pratten's plea. I recognise that the Minister has been very firm indeed in the consideration of this measure. I do not believe that the amendment would concern many companies. There is not the slightest doubt that metals for hardening steel are indispensable at present, and that the very life of our nation depends upon their production. The producers deserve our encouragement in every possible way. It is not a very big concession to . make, and the harmony thereby restored would be so great that I think that we would get through with the Bill very quickly..
- I rise to order. Does a suspension of the Sessional Orders do away with the necessity of putting from the Chair, at 4 o'clock, the question, " That the Senate do now adjourn " ?
- Yes.
.- I think that Senator Grant will bear me out that there would be great injustice inflicted if this little amendment were carried.
- Then defeat the amendment.

- We interviewed a gentleman yesterday in connexion with a tungsten company. He -informed me that it had been at work for three years and had made no profit. If the company were to strike a patch, just now, it would be very hard indeed, after having struggled along for three years, that it should not get the full benefit of the price of metals, which are so badly required by the British Government. The suggestion made is that all companies producing these metals should be exempted from the tax. It was admitted by the Minister today that such companies are selling the metals at half the world's parity to the British Government.. I am not going to criticise that statement/
- It must pay the companies to do it.

- I have mentioned a specific, instance in which it has not paid the company. It came under the notice of Senator Grant and myself only this morning. I suggest that it would be a fair thing to eliminate the accident of age.

.- From the outset I have set my face against allowing any exemptions from the tax. It will be. remembered that I said in my second-reading speech that if any department of trade and commerce could claim consideration, it was mining. I uTged that mining is so much of a lottery that, if any consideration could be granted to any series of profit, it ought to be extended to. mining.
- Why to mining? .
- Because it is so speculative, and because, on the whole, it is unr profitable.
- I heard that statement made about farming.

- On the whole, farming, is not unprofitable. More money is lost in mining than in any other industry. Therefore, if anything claims considers* ation for an exempation, it is mining. This proposal, if adopted, will create much dissatisfaction. From a certain day this form of mining will be exempted, but if some persons were fortunate enough to start a mining venture a week before, that date they will be liable to the tax. It may be said that a line has to be drawn somewhere, but I do not know that it has. If honorable senators are in favour of exempting mining for metals, let them exempt mining altogether. If it is decided to exempt one class of metals, I shall vote to exempt the lot. I shall support Senator Bakhap, because it appears to me that tin and zinc are as much required in the manufacture of munitions as are the others which have been mentioned.
- Will you exempt copper and lead?
- Copper is used very largely in the manufacture of . munitions, and so is tin.
- Will you exempt copper ?

- I will help to exempt most of these metals, and I think that I shall be quite justified in doing so. The trouble is that from the very start this measure is inequitable. I do not believe that one honorable senator can say conscientiously that it is anywhere near being an equitable measure. It is not proposed to levy a tax on inordinate and excessive profits, but to tax the profits' in excess at one time over another. A thousand, examples could be given to show the enormity of the proposal. I am. still of the opinion, notwithstanding all the discussion which has taken place,, that this legislation will be so repulsive to the people of Australia that there will be a strong demand to repeal the Act before it has been in existence very long. If the amendment is carried I shall feel at liberty to support exemptions in other directions with regard to mining.
- Can an amendment be moved to amend the amendment that has just been carried?

speech.para: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN".No; but the clause is still open to amendment.

talk.start.para: . - Seeing that the Administration, as represented by Senator Millen, is practically dumb in regard to all advances for the embodiment of an absolutely equitable proposal in this measure, I must take the responsibility of submitting an amendment which, if carried, will remove the possibility of many injustices being done. Why wolfram mines, scheelite mines, and molybdenite mines started since the 4th August, '1914, should be exempted, and mines which were started before that date, but which have only become profit bearing during the war period, should be liable to the tax, passes my comprehension. It may be that I have been damned by nature with certain obtuseness which prevents me from seeing where the symmetry of granting relief in one case and refusing to grant it in another lies. But the fact is that I am absolutely astounded at an amendment of this kind having the limitations placed upon it which the Minister, by his silence, seems to desire to be attached Ito it. The principle for which I contend is that the production of any commodity - I do not care whether it is tin or beetroot- that has resulted in profits which cannot be traced to war conditions should be exempted from the operation of this measure. I care very little whether it can be demonstrated that the tin miner has not benefited on the average during the war period because of . any appreciation in the value of the metal. I am concerned that profits shall not be taxed when they have been made quite outside the influence of conditions created by the war. I desire to move -

quote.para: That the following new sub-clause be inserted : - " 4. No company nor any individual engaged solely in the production of any commodity, not covered by the exemptions in this Act, the average price of which during the first three yars of the war does not exceed the average price of the commodity during the three years prior to the first July, 1914, shall be taxed under the provisions of this Act in respect to profits made during the first three years of the war; but if the average price of the commodity increases in any subsequent waT year beyond the average of the price of the commodity during the three year pre-war period then for any such war year the provisions of this Act shall apply." I do not care what the commodity is, unless it has been specifically exempted by the measure, if it has not benefited by an increase in price during the years of the war, the profits made in the production of the commodity should not be taxed. There is no mention of any particular article. It may be ore or anything else.

talk.start.para: - But if the profits are attributable to war conditions, what then?

- In that case, the profits would be levied upon. I do not propose to exempt them, from the provisions of the Bill unless they have been specifically exempted. Moreover, my amendment does not shut out the industry from the operation of the measure if in subsequent war years the price advances beyond the average of the pre-war period.

speech.para: I wish to be just all round. I desire to be just to the Treasurer, because money has to be raised. I embody in this subclause a principle which should have permeated the whole measure, namely, the taxation, without exemption if you like, of all profits directly attributable to war conditions. This will exempt the tin-producing industry, for it can be demonstrated by statistics, for which the biggest tin corporation in Australia is responsible, that tin has not appreciated in price since the war. I will extend the exemption to the profits on any commodity not directly attributable to - an appreciating market created by war conditions. I shall move the amendment as sub-clause 4 of clause 8, and believe that it will give the necessary relief to industries that have earned profits not attributable to war conditions.

talk.start.para: . - I have a prior amendment. I move -

quote.para: That in sub-clause 3 the following words be left out : - " and whose military or naval duties require him to be in any part of the field of operations in connexion with the war, where there is danger to Ufa as a result of the operations of enemy forces."

speech.para: I have been moved to suggest the omission of these words by a desire that the position may be more clearly defined. If they remain in the Bill they may place in the hands of the officer commanding a regiment the right to decide whether the life of a prospective taxpayer has been endangered or not. Some may consider positions in the Army Medical Corps or Army Service Corps to be those in which life is endangered, and complicated definitions may be required in other respects. Is it a danger to life to go on a troopship and risk sinking by torpedoes? Is it a danger to life to go to England, or must it be defined as being " within the sphere of gun-fire"? A phrase like this must give rise to a good deal of dissatisfaction, and requires to he carefully defined. If a man was not popular with his superior officer, he might be unjustly brought within the provisions of the Act.

talk.start.para: . - Officers, sent to Great Britain and other parts of thu world, far away from any scene of active warfare, and in no sense involving danger to themselves, have, for certain reasons, been made members of the Australian Imperial Force and put on an Australian Imperial Force rating. If this amendment were carried, an officer of that kind, sent to America, could claim to be entitled to a concession meant only for those taking an active part in the war. Certain officers who are pure civilians have been sent to England. They were given military rank because they had deal with the civil side of the military organization. It was not intended, and it is not equitable, that they should be able to claim this concession.
- Do you define those referred to in the clause as men who serve within the sphere of war-like operations ?

- The words are necessary to exclude from the benefits of this clause men who are not taking an active part in military operations. It will not be left to any commanding officer to define "field of operations" or " danger to life." That will be prescribed by regulation. I assume that all those who go as combatants will get the benefit of the clause. The purpose is to shut out those who have gone merely in civil capacities, although bearing military titles and on the military pay-sheet. Many names will occur to the honorable senator.
. - I hope no responsibility, will be placed upon commanding officers to interpret this clause. Every man who volunteers as a combatant should be re-1 garded as in the danger zone.
- I agree with you. Every man who volunteers for service in the active army.
- Yes ; many of our men are engaged far behindTthe lines, safe from shot and shell for the time being, but they did not go to those positions of their own volition.

- Take Brigadier-General Anderson as an illustration of the cases I mentioned. He is a civilian, who was merely given military rank, not because he was a military man, but because he had to deal with military matters.
- I want to see every man who volunteers for war purposes given the benefit of this clause.
- Brigadier-General Anderson may claim, in certain circumstances, that his life had been endangered by, German submarines.

- Let him claim it. It will not affect my vote. The same thing might apply to those who have left Australia as ordinary passengers. Those who travel by rail or sea. risk their lives. I can well understand now that the Minister means that every man who volunteers for war activities will be covered. If the Committee were to strike out the words which Senator Pratten proposes to omit, it would do an injustice to a great many men who aTe serving us at the Front to-day.

.- This appears to me to have been a provision hastily inserted, with the object of doing a service to our men at the Front; but I take the view that it will, at the most, benefit only one in every thousand. I presume that of the 360,000 men who have left for the Front there is not more than one in a thousand who will reap the benefit of this provision. That being so, I would strike it out altogether- The few who derive excessive profits from businesses that they were controlling before they left for the Front - profits obtained from the dependants of others who are serving us - will be benefited, while the great bulk of our men at the Front will receive no benefit whatever from it.

. - Having heard the very definite statement of the Vice-President of the Executive Council (Senator Millen) that a regulation will be framed under which the danger area will be specified, so that there is not likely to be half-a-dozen different definitions of the danger zone, I am perfectly satisfied, and beg leave to withdraw by amendment.

quote.para: That the following new sub-clause be inserted: - " (4.) No company nor any individual engaged solely in the production of any commodity, not covered by the exemptions in this Act, the average price of which during the first three years of the war does not exceed the average price of the commodity during the three year prior o the first July, One thousand nine hundred and fourteen, shall be taxed under the provisions of this. Act in respect to profits made during the. first three years of the war; but if the average price of the commodity increases in any subsequent war year beyond the average of the price of the commodity during the three year pre-war period then for any such war year the provisions of this Act shall apply."

talk.start.para: . - I am sure that Senator Bakhap will not expect me to debate at any length the merits of his proposal. It waa elaborated by him last night, and outs right across the basis of the present Bill. It is, indeed, .a clear challenge to the principle of the Bill. I take no exception to the action of the honorable senator in submitting the amendment, but to accept it would be to destroy the Bill. The honorable senator is putting up an entirely new proposition, . In addition, if the amendment .were agreed to, it would remove from this Bill all exemptions- ' "We have already decided that there shall be exemptions.

- My amendment does not set aside exemptions. I am dealing with the measure as it stands. The honorable senator has said it is a Wartime Profits Tax Bill, and he makes a distinction between such a measure and a tax on war profits.

- The honorable senator is perfectly right, and I, therefore,' do not think I need detain the Committee. This Bill sets out to levy a tax on excess profits earned during the currency of the war, as compared with profits of the pre-war years. The honorable senator now proposes something entirely different. To accept his amendment would be to abandon the Bill, and that I cannot do.

. - I cannot grant that the Minister's contention is at all correct. As regards the general principle of the measure, I have combated the view that taxation should be levied on profits during the war period that are not traceable to war conditions. I have said that in the minds of most people who are concerned about, this measure the idea existed that' it was to tax profits traceable to the war. On- the occasion of the commercial travellers' celebrations, held only last month, so responsible a member of the Cabinet as the Minister for Works and Railways (Mr. Watt) who proposed the toast of the evening, referred to this measure in the presence of a large body of commercial men as a War Profits Bill. That statement appears in the official report of his speech, as published in the Commercial Traveller. ' A change has evidently come over the spirit of the dream, for dream it is, that the people will accept this as an equitable measure.
- It seems to be a nightmare to the honorable senator.

- And it will be to the honorable senator's constituents. We are members' of a Chamber of review, and when dealing with an important taxation measure like this, it is our duty, irrespective of party, to remove from it any injustice that -we are capable of removing. I am sorry that there has grown up among Australian Ministers - and. I suppose it is inseparable from the Cabinet system of government - the feeling that they must secure every line of a measure of which they are in charge. They seem to resent amendments - to think it derogatory to their Ministerial dignity to accept any, and to believe that amendments are suggested in a spirit of antagonism. They appear to completely forget the larger principle which should animate us here, namely, that we should do justice to the people -when putting into practical operation so important a principle of taxation as this. .1- give willingly to the Minister, and to any honorable senator supporting him, the duty of explaining to the public the equity and symmetry of these clauses, when they compare the effect of the amendment embodied in the Bill, on the motion of Senator Fairbairn, in giving relief to certain industries, with the inequitable incidence of this measure as it will inevitably operate in connexion with similar industries established, a little before the war period. The Minister has said that my amendment would do away with all exemptions. That is not so. If anything is exempt under the Bill, that exemption will stand. But my proposed new sub-clause will protect any industry not specifically exempted in regard to its productions, if those productions have not appreciated in value during the war period. Will any honorable senator have the hardihood to say that profits earned during the war period, and not 'fcraceaible in any sense to war conditions, should be taxed, while larger profits earned by smaller- enterprises established before the waT, and with the pre- WW standard of comparison, escape? The whole thing is iniquitous to a degree. However, I shall not labour the question/ I throw upon the Ministry and those who are supporting them the responsibility for justifying this measure to the country. Seeing the spirit in which Ministers regard the Bill, I ajn doing my best to make its provisions, as equitable as possible. I am not even asking that the specific industry which I have championed shall be exempted. But I do urge that profits which are' not traceable to war .conditions ought to be' exempted. However, I have discharged my duty, and the Government must accept responsibility for the measure which, I venture to say, they will be- urging us to amend in the' short space of a few months.

. - I -pledged myself to support a War Profits Bill. The other evening 1 affirmed that this measure is not 'a "War Profits Bill, but a Wax-time ' Profits Bill. If I were to occupy half-an-hour in discussing the matter, I could not put the position' more clearly than it has already been put by Senator Bakhap. His amendment- meets my views, and is consonant with my pledges. I shall support it, particularly .'because its adoption would do away - with the injustices to which such frequent reference has been made, by reason of the discrimination that is -made in the Bill between various metals. -
